title: Part 1
content:
Part 1

AT 3:20 P.M., with forty minutes left until the end of the exam, I made my way to the center of E11, asking Beppu for the enemy's position every step of the way.

"...They're coming. All three of them, they're really close now, right in front of us...! What if Ryuuen and Ibuki split up...? What should I do?"

"That's unlikely. Yamashita isn't very athletic and she's probably nearing her limit. She can't keep up with your pace as a guy and it wouldn't be easy for them to track you with a five-minute delay taken into account."

"I hope you're right... To be honest, I'm at my absolute limit..."

He gave a wry smile, his legs screaming after having walked and run around the deserted island for nearly four days.

"In that case, all you can do is lie low and pray they don't find you."

"Yeah, I'd rather not do that..."

Considering the remaining time, he would almost certainly be found and taken out.

"You're in there, aren't you! Ayanokouji! You should be grateful I came all this way for a fight!"

From ahead, Ibuki's shout reached me.

"What's with her, is she a tsundere or something...? Well, I'm outta here, then?"

After making his light-hearted jab, Beppu raised a hand and quietly departed.

I tore my gaze from his retreating figure and moved forward, one step at a time.

With the eliminated students having withdrawn, the deserted island was now sparsely populated. The surrounding sounds were clearer than ever.

It’d been a survival game where, until now, everyone fired without question upon seeing an enemy.

But as I walked onward, both Ryuuen and Ibuki emerged from between the trees.

Faintly behind them, I could also see Yamashita.

"Hah, we've been playing this exam seriously, all trial and error, but in the end, it's just a flashy shootout with no brains involved that wears everyone down. It's no wonder an idiot like Ibuki, who can at least move, is still standing, right?"

"Sounds like you were pretty successful. How many people did you take out?"

"I don't remember how many I beat. Besides, because those three Class A VIPs got eliminated, I missed my chance to take down Horikita!"

She seemed frustrated about that, her voice laced with anger.

"I don't like it, but it's thanks to the information you sent. A convergence of interests, I suppose?"

Judging by the deadlocked results, Class A might have been the one left standing if I hadn't passed on the information.

"It would be a problem for the other three classes if Class A didn't lose. Right?"

"Yeah. But I'd like to hand you a loss just as much. Time's running out. Let's settle this here and now and decide our ranks."

His low voice echoed from straight ahead. As Yamashita fell back, both of them disappeared between the trees.

Of course, they wouldn't think of a two-on-one as cowardly.

If it were a normal fight, they would’ve realized they had no chance of winning and wouldn't have taken the bait.

But this time, the situation was different. They could defeat me just by hitting me with a paintball.

Without bothering to take cover, I advanced to see what my opponents would do.

I couldn't be careless at a distance of less than ten meters, but there were still more than twenty meters between us. It wasn't too late to react after seeing the muzzle of a gun.

Or rather, you could say it was because I didn't have enough ammo left for a long-range firefight.

Ammunition unilaterally favors the side that has more of it. But an advantage doesn't necessarily guarantee victory. I had about twenty rounds left. All of my actions needed to be structured by calculation. Without taking a deep breath, I calmly processed the variables before me: distance, angle of cover, Ibuki's habits, Ryuuen's line of fire.

"Die, Ayanokouji!"

Ibuki, who went out of her way to shout, reminded me of Ishizaki, who I fought on the rooftop.

Immediately after, a submachine gun poked out and fired off a somewhat random spray of bullets.

That wasn't meant to take me down, but to serve as bait—to make me take cover, cutting off my sight and hearing so I wouldn't know Ryuuen's position. Submachine guns have little ammunition.

The moment she fired off all thirty rounds, I kicked off the ground and closed the distance to Ibuki.

Seeing this, Ibuki spun around and slipped low between the trees.

I dropped my stance and fired a short burst. The trajectory wavered slightly, shaving off one leaf, then another and grazed Ibuki's shoulder, but since the paintball didn't burst, her wristwatch didn't signal a hit. Ibuki glared at me, her teeth bared in a grimace that resembled a smile.

Then she hid securely behind a tree and began to reload. Since I didn't know Ryuuen's current location, it was difficult to flank her to close the distance.

The faint sound of scraping plastic reached me. Taking that as my cue, I moved a few steps to the side. By changing my position, I altered the line of fire and peeked through the trees to assess the situation.

Deep among the trees, Ibuki's shadow moved slightly.

The moment I confirmed a gun muzzle peeking out in the corner of my vision, I reflexively dropped my body low.

The sound of a paintball slicing through the air rushed past, practically grazing my ear, before it splattered against the bark of a tree behind me.

Before I could even confirm the miss, Ryuuen was already moving to a new position. I wanted to follow him with my eyes, but Ibuki, having finished reloading, had started moving again, so I broke my line of sight.

"She's fast, as expected."

The petite Ibuki moved between the trees, running like a small animal. Moreover, she seemed accustomed to shooting with some accuracy while running. Bullets flew sporadically from her lightweight submachine gun, striking the large tree that was protecting me.

Wary of her getting behind me, I took a few steps back and changed my position as well.

Faster than the eye could follow, a branch swayed and leaves danced.

Predicting her line of movement, I fired two bursts.

The bullets struck the trunk and wood chips flew.

It wasn't a direct hit, but it was enough to stop Ibuki's advance for just a moment.

"Where are you even aiming? You think you're gonna hit me with a shot that pathetic? You're a lousy shot."

Ibuki's voice echoed between the trees.

It was a provocation. But I didn't answer, just regulated my breathing.

Ibuki showed her face again.

There was even a smile on her face. Was it confidence, or perhaps overconfidence?

But as there was no hesitation in her movements, their straightforward predictability remained unchanged.

The position of her hips the moment she jumped out, the height of her gaze, everything was consistent.

And then, at that moment, Ryuuen moved again, scattering paintballs in my direction.

In a situation where one hit meant it was over, my attention was unwillingly diverted and I focused on evasion.

Then I pulled the trigger three times toward Ryuuen as a warning, forcing him to back down. I had only taken my eyes off her for two or three seconds before turning my body and gaze toward the spot where I thought Ibuki had last hidden.

"Gotcha—!"

The shout came from two trees over from where I had set my sights.

Thinking I hadn't noticed she moved, she boldly revealed herself and took aim at me.

"Wha—!?"

It was true that I was looking at the place where Ibuki had hidden just a few seconds before. My body was facing that direction, too, but there was one thing that wasn't: the muzzle of the weapon held firmly in my hand. The muzzle alone was pointed toward Ibuki, who just jumped out, seeing her chance to win.

I confirmed the feel of my finger on the trigger and pulled.

The bullet's trajectory cut through the air, flying in a straight line.

Ibuki reflexively twisted her body, but she couldn't completely dodge it.

A paintball hit her right thigh and burst. The judging tone echoed through the forest a moment later.

Ibuki’s eyes widened in surprise and she collapsed onto the ground. The electronic sound repeated.

"Agh, dammit! So this is how it ends!? This is so fucking annoying!! I told you I didn't want to do this!"

I had no time to listen to Ibuki's bitter complaints as the wind stirred behind me. I immediately turned and pulled the trigger on Ryuuen, who was aiming at me. But the gun didn't fire. Meanwhile, Ryuuen had fired while moving his body, so his shot barely missed my shoulder and failed to hit.

"Out of ammo here—"

With my weapon in one hand, I broke into a run, heading south.

He looked calm at a glance, but in truth, he pursued me without hesitation, like a beast about to pounce.

That was the price for using up too much ammo on the small stuff.

Right as I finished off Ibuki, the magazine was clearly and completely empty.

Not a single paintball remained in my assault rifle.

I bluffed by aiming behind me, but Ryuuen continued to advance without flinching at all.

A determined pursuit, shouldering the risk of his own defeat.

My watch showed that the area had switched to E12.

But I had no time to look closely at my watch.

As straight and as short as possible, but the deep forest would not let me escape so easily.

To the right, to the left, sometimes from underfoot.

Nature attacked, preventing me from running at full speed.

A paintball came flying from behind.

Unable to worry about appearances any longer, I threw the cumbersome weapon in my right hand onto the ground.

What awaited me beyond the forest was, of course, a sprawling sandy beach.

There was no cover at all.

I stopped after running about twenty meters across the sand.

"I surrender."

I raised both my hands and said so to Ryuuen, who aimed his weapon at me from behind.

"So even you can't dodge every bullet here, can you?"

A calmer voice than I'd expected came from behind me, though he was out of breath.

"Impossible. There's no way I can dodge them all."

If it’d been a concrete surface where my feet wouldn't get stuck in the sand, could I have put up a bit more of a fight? No, that was probably impossible.

If my opponent only had one or two shots left, it would’ve been a different story, but that wasn't the case.

That slim possibility had just vanished with the clack of a magazine being replaced.

"Gotta take every precaution when I'm up against you, Ayanokouji, right?"

"—Maybe. But why did you decide to fight me? It seemed like Ibuki was against it."

"Even in a 2-v-1, there's no guarantee we'd win a shootout against you. She probably thought she had a better chance of winning if she took an all-or-nothing shot at the VIP."

With my hands still in the air, I moved only my neck to look behind me.

"And you thought differently?"

"Nah. If it were just about winning, I'd have thought that was the better move, too. But settling things by running away on a rare occasion like this? That ain't any fun at all. A far cry from victory."

Ryuuen had racked up loss after loss until now; perhaps his obsession with victory had led to this 2-v-1.

"I understand your reason. But if that's the case, why haven't you shot me now that you've finished reloading? If the victory you desire is to defeat me, you're one step away from achieving it. All you have to do is put some force into your fingertip and pull the trigger and it'll all be over."

Without even a one percent shred of a lie, that decision would get me eliminated.

But the reason he didn't was likely because he wanted a certain victory.

Even though he already won, he couldn't believe he could actually win.

"Hah—you've got a point. I've gotten pissed off watching scenes like this in movies and shows myself. Like, 'If you've got time to talk, just shoot already.'"

"Correct. While we're standing here like this, Yamashita might be getting targeted by one of our guards."

"Maybe. But there are things you only understand when you're in a situation like this yourself."

Ryuuen was laughing, but he hadn't let his guard down in the slightest.

He wasn't getting too comfortable with his overwhelming advantage.

"I just wanna know, is this really you surrendering? How is the one existence I thought I couldn't beat going to escape this predicament? Or do you even think you can escape? If you do, I wanna see it. Even if it means risking my own defeat."

After taking a breath, Ryuuen took a single half-step back from me without changing his posture at all.

"No matter who you are, there's no way you can dodge every single bullet I fire, right?"

"I already told you it's impossible. The muzzle velocity of these paint guns is about 90 m/s. Meanwhile, the average human reaction time is 0.2 to 0.3 seconds. If we were about 20 meters apart, there'd be some leeway, but at this distance, it's hopeless. Even if I could instinctively dodge a few shots, it's absolutely impossible to keep dodging them all until the magazine is empty."

I glanced around lightly and stated the objective situation.

"If there were no rules, I might have the option of taking that slim chance to dodge, close the distance and disarm you—but taking a weapon is obviously prohibited. Or if I had a handgun, I could’ve at least fought back, but anyone carrying a handgun is required to wear a holster visibly on their leg, so it's impossible to conceal one. With both overpowering you and fighting back sealed off, the only thing I can do now is keep dodging."

Ryuuen glanced at my feet to double-check.

Of course, I didn't have a handgun.

"Yeah, that's right. No matter how you look at it, you're cornered."

"You've cornered me this perfectly and you're still telling me to show you a way out?"

"I'd like to see it, but—if you can't, you can't. I'll take you down and go hunt the remaining VIP and guards. You're betting everything on your last remaining guard, huh?"

Readjusting his firm grip on the gun, Ryuuen lowered his tone of voice a notch.

Considering the time remaining, he would have to finish me off soon and re-enter the forest.

"Bet everything on the last guard... That's not a bad suggestion."

"The ones left are Kanzaki and Yamamura? Sorry, but I ain't got any intention of losing to small fry."

"Is that so? I'd say that depends on the conditions."

Sensing something ominous in my words, Ryuuen furrowed his brow.

"Keep walking forward a few more meters. Right, stop there."

Ryuuen made me walk, then stomped his foot on the sandy spot where I had just been standing.

"Guess there's no way you pulled a trick like luring me here to a spot where you'd buried a weapon, huh."

It seemed he considered the less than one percent possibility and wanted to eliminate it.

"The idea of being lured isn't a bad line of thought. After I ran out of ammo, I threw down my weapon and ran away from you, but can you really say I was just running away?"

"...Huh?"

"Doesn't it feel a little strange—that I fled frantically, got lost, left the forest and ran onto this beach? The area we can move through is already limited, but there's no way I haven't memorized the map. If I were going to run anyway, it would’ve been a hundred times better to keep running in circles inside the forest. There's no merit to fleeing to a beach like this with no cover whatsoever, where the sand trips you up so you can't run properly and you can't even dodge."

"...'Cause the forest has all the damn cover you could want. But still, I don't get it. Why would you lure me here, to a place that only gives me the advantage?"

"It's a matter of perspective. Having no cover leaves you defenseless, but at the same time, it leaves your opponent defenseless too. It's an environment where even a poor shot can hit an enemy with a paintball if they pull the trigger up close."

Ryuuen's brow furrowed even more.

After all, it was a simple fact that while it was advantageous to Ryuuen, it wasn't to me.

"And the forest is too quiet. But here, you can clearly hear the sound of the wind and waves. The risk of making unnecessary noise by stepping on a twig is low. It's the perfect place to sneak up from behind."

"From behind...?"

Ryuuen couldn't carelessly look away from me, knowing I was not to be underestimated.

I continued to throw words at Ryuuen, who must have been starting to feel a chill down his spine.

"You were chasing me. But at the same time, I was giving orders to my remaining guard. I told them that once it was confirmed to be one-on-one, I would lure Ryuuen to this spot, so they should approach from behind and finish him off—"

"And you think I wouldn't notice?"

"Could you really? You focused completely on chasing me. It was a pursuit that could be called obsessive. But as a result, it's hard to say your awareness of what was behind you was perfect. Are you not aware of the reality of your situation, that you have a gun pointed at you, as if someone is aiming from a few meters behind you right now?"

"Don't make me laugh. That's a bluff."

"You think you'd definitely know if someone approached? But one of my remaining guards is Yamamura. She's skilled at erasing her presence, she's lightweight and nimble. She doesn't have great athletic ability, but she's one of the most suitable people for sneaking up quietly."

Amidst the quiet, repeating sound of the waves, Ryuuen strained his ears.

But it would be difficult to pick up the breathing of an opponent who was standing still.

"If Yamamura is behind me... then why haven't you had her shoot?"

"Same as you. You wanted to get all the answers, didn't you?"

"Kuku... This is what makes it so damn interesting. I thought I'd cornered you into a situation where I was under absolutely no threat, but you've made me consider the 'what if.' Let's say, just for argument's sake, that Yamamura is behind me. What would you do if I turned around and counterattacked before she could fire? Yamamura would be out and I'd be sure to shoot you down before you could pick up her weapon."

"That might happen, or it might not. If you're curious, you can always test it."

I could tell that Ryuuen, standing before me, took a sharp breath.

Unlike before, he was becoming very wary of his unseen back.

If Yamamura was standing behind him—

As the last guard, that would mean game over.

He thought. Was he really being followed without noticing?

No, that couldn't be, he thought, yet doubt remained as to whether he’d been paying attention to his back.

The important thing wasn’t whether she was there or not.

It was that he had to act under the assumption that she was.

He had to turn around quickly and land a paintball on Yamamura before she could shoot.

Even if he could manage that without difficulty, if by some chance a shot was fired before Yamamura was ruled out, Ryuuen would have to dodge that paintball at all costs. That wouldn’t be easy.

Then again, trying to take me out first was nonsense. He'd just get shot by Yamamura in the meantime and it would be over.

I could read Ryuuen's thoughts as if they were my own.

He couldn’t ignore what was behind him.

Above all, since I didn't have a gun, his only option was to dodge.

In that case, there was no harm in glancing behind for a moment.

If no one was there, he just had to return his gaze and posture to normal in less than a second.

Even if I tried to run, I wouldn't get far on this wide beach, as my footing would be poor.

Just after he let out a faint breath—

He twisted his body, turning around with the muzzle of his gun.

Ryuuen's field of vision. The forest visible in the distance and the deserted beach.

There was no one behind him.

A moment of relief.

All that was left was to turn back toward me and shoot the one without a weapon to secure his victory.

But faster than his gaze could return, I put a great deal of strength into my right hand.

It was true that I held no weapon.

Nor did I have any means of escape.

However—I did have the means to fight.

I, too, twisted my body around toward Ryuuen.

Convinced of his victory, Ryuuen turned back to me and pulled the finger that was already on the trigger.

I could not dodge all the bullets that would fly out, but that wasn’t a problem.

Between the index finger and thumb of my right hand.

A single, damaged paintball was wedged there.

With all my might, I threw it at Ryuuen, like a pitcher throwing into a mitt.

At the same time my abdomen was stained, Ryuuen's abdomen was stained the same color.

"Wh—!?"

Only the faint hum of the motor that fired the pellet remained.

Almost simultaneously, our watches beeped, announcing we were out and sealing both our defeats.

This paintball was fundamentally the same as the ones loaded in the magazine, but with one key difference. Normally, it wouldn't break easily even if a person hit their target by throwing it.

Repeated trial and error.

How much force was needed to break it on impact?

How hard of a surface did it need to hit to break?

What was the most efficient method?

How damaged did the membrane preventing the paintball from bursting need to be for it to rupture?

It was something I spent time preparing over the past three days, repeating trials to create the perfect amount of damage so that it wouldn't break.

"You... threw it...!?"

"There's nothing in the rules against it. It's just that using a weapon is more reliable and convenient, so it's something nobody needs to do."

Ryuuen glared at the obnoxiously loud alarm on his watch and slammed his weapon onto the ground.

"Did you drag this out just to show off some tricky little stunt? What if I'd pulled the trigger without hesitating? You wouldn't have had any time for a counterattack like this."

"The moment I lured you to the beach, your overwhelming advantage was guaranteed. I predicted with high probability that you wouldn't shoot me right away. Besides, I had my own circumstances to consider. While it's true I wanted to purely enjoy the match, ultimately, I was fine with losing here. Because I'd already achieved my goal."

"...Your goal?"

"I'll make it official here. I, Class D and Ichinose have joined forces. I can't say how far this alliance will go or to what extent, but we are united in aiming for the top. But even if you call it an alliance, the other students, especially those in Class C, wouldn't just accept it. That's why my top priority was to drive them into a situation where they had no choice but to form one."

"So that's what this was about. In other words, the reason my surprise attack worked was—"

"Yes. The time of highest risk in this special exam is when the classes are close to each other. Barring the final phase, the starting point is the most dangerous. Everyone rushes to move away from the other classes. They communicate constantly with their commander via GPS to confirm they're putting distance between them. You wouldn't have thought to use your strategy from the get-go if we quickly moved away, either."

But in reality, as soon as Class C confirmed the other classes moved away, they stopped in their tracks.

"By making it seem like we shifted our focus to teaching how to use the weapons first and formulating a strategy, I created an environment that was easy for a surprise attack."

"So you left your classmates defenseless and let them take the hit?"

"That's right. Unfortunately for you, winning a shootout wasn't my first priority. I just wanted to create a situation where Class C would have no choice but to rely on Class D, whether they liked it or not."

Even Hashimoto and Morishita, who were relatively well-informed, were highly skeptical of the alliance.

And for good reason. They felt there were more disadvantages than advantages to teaming up with Class D, who’d so far shown few notable achievements. Even if you simply said you’d form an alliance, it wasn't something they could easily accept.

However, if they were cornered, it was a different story. If they couldn't find a way to survive the special exam without Class D's help, it was a different story. If a path to second or third place opened up on the road to rock bottom, it was a different story.

And so, the Class C students came to plead for Class D's cooperation on their own.

"Of course, we probably could have forced an alliance even without the surprise attack. But what do you think would’ve happened if an unscathed Class C and Class D had joined hands? Even someone as bold as you would find it reckless to challenge nearly eighty opponents. That's why you can't easily make a move even against a moderately weakened Class C and D alliance. On the other hand, Class A would feel similarly. They'd think that at this rate, it would become a muddy battle between Class A and Class B for last place."

Ryuuen, too, spread out the map in his mind, tracing what he would’ve done.

"In that case, this thought naturally arises: 'Perhaps we could join forces with Class B just for this special exam, crush the lower classes first and then settle things between us.'"

Do what the opponent did to get back on even footing.

Of course, it wouldn't be easy. They might not be able to build enough mutual trust to act as a completely unified front like Classes C and D. However, there was a possibility they could build a cooperative relationship strong enough to avoid direct conflict and pincer the C-D alliance.

"I never would've thought you'd take a surprise attack on purpose... So you're saying I shouldn't have done it?"

"It was a matter of sooner or later. The reason I had you attack the waiting Class C on the second day was also because I wanted to wear down our forces a little more. There were any number of ways to break my allies' spirits."

That defeat on the second day was the clincher.

Realizing they had no other choice, the Class C students personally requested an alliance with Class D.

"In the end, that idiot Ibuki was the most right, huh. This is the pathetic result of being too damn fixated on you."

A declaration of defeat. But it was somehow different from the pathetic figure he’d cut in the classroom last time.

"I've seen your process of using any environment to win. In that case, from here on out, I'm not gonna show you any mercy in the truest sense."

"So you've been holding back on me until now? How very kind of you."

Ryuuen slowly picked up his weapon, averted his gaze from me and stared out at the sea.

Then, without responding to my words, he started walking down the beach. After watching him go, I turned back once to retrieve the weapon I intentionally dropped, then returned to the base, arriving late.

Then I returned to the ship and waited. Although we were told we were free until the end of the special exam, there wasn't enough time to do anything and the scheduled time arrived just like that.

There hadn't been an official announcement yet, but with Class A already wiped out and Class B without its guard, there was almost no doubt that Class A would be last, Class B third, Class C second and Class D first. Since Horikita and Koenji in Class A had Protection Points, there would be no expulsions.

Just as Hashimoto came over to offer me words of praise, an announcement was made for us to disembark.

It seemed the results of the special exam would be announced outside.

As we started walking to disembark together, students nearby muttered about what a tough exam it’d been, but was that really the case? The previous special exam and then this special exam. It was certainly true that this one had been harsh in comparison, due to the long period of isolation, the considerable fluctuation in Class Points and the fact that a student would be selected for expulsion, even if they could be protected by a Protection Point.

When we got down to the wharf, we were instructed to freely take one bottle from several types of labeled plastic bottles lined up, but they were all water and tasted the same, so I grabbed one at random before stepping onto the sandy beach. It seemed there was no need to line up by class, as a teacher told us to wait wherever we wanted.

My eyes searched for Hiyori, whom I hadn't seen once during this deserted island exam.

And in the distance, I found her talking with our classmate Kaneda.

She didn't look injured or unwell; she seemed to be in good spirits.

I wondered whether or not I should go talk to her.

As I pondered for a moment, Yoshida, who spotted me and Hashimoto, rushed over, resting his elbow on my shoulder with a grin to celebrate our second-place finish.

Unable to move as I pleased, the three of us simply waited as time passed.

The teachers moved about frantically.

For a simple special exam results announcement, the atmosphere was strangely solemn.

It wasn't the state of each class, but the teachers' demeanor that was odd.

Even Hoshinomiya-sensei, who should’ve been suppressing her joy, wasn't letting her guard down at all.

Something was definitely off.

Even Hashimoto and Yoshida, who hadn't noticed at first, picked up on the strangeness.

The newly brought-in cardboard boxes were completely unopened.

"Man, don't you get a really bad feeling about this?"

"...What a coincidence, Hashimoto. I was just about to say the same thing."

Both of us sensed the strangeness and realized that something new was beginning.

Eventually, the exhausted Yamamura and the others were led back to the base by a teacher and as soon as the last survivors were gathered, they were made to stand on the beach with no time to rest.

There was a clear difference in physical condition and stamina between the students who were eliminated early on and those who had survived until the end, but no consideration was shown for it.

Or perhaps even this difference was all just a prelude to what was coming next.

As the students watched, Mashima-sensei picked up a megaphone and brought it to his mouth.

"The Uninhabited Island Survival Game Special Exam is hereby concluded—"

What should’ve followed those words was the announcement of the results.

But they changed into words that confirmed the oppressive atmosphere the students felt was real.

"From this moment, the Uninhabited Island Special Exam will now begin."

Those were words that heralded a new battle.

This was something entirely different from the 'lenient' survival game, whose penalties were little more than an extension of play.

The curtain rose on the school's battle of 'trust' and 'betrayal' to sift through the students and determine whether they were worthy of graduation.

prevChapter.title: Epilogue: Show Me What Youve Got

toc.label: Classroom of the Elite  Year 3, Volume 3
Chapter 1: Opening. Survival Game Special Exam.
Chapter 7: The Time of the Decisive Battle
Epilogue: Show Me What Youve Got
